docs.snippet: SINCE she took over the role of the spymaster M in the James Bond movies, and came close to winning an Oscar for her portrayal of Queen Victoria in ''Mrs. Brown,'' Judi Dench's mailbag has vastly increased. She has become accustomed to getting let...
docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE she took over the role of the spymaster M in the James Bond movies, and came close to winning an Oscar for her portrayal of Queen Victoria in ''Mrs. Brown,'' Judi Dench's mailbag has vastly increased. She has become accustomed to getting letters, mostly from America, asking her where she has been hiding and what acting she has done. If she were a pedantic person, she might reply that, well, she has been playing leading roles in the theater for four decades and that her work onstage won her the title of Dame of the British Empire in 1988. If she were feeling immodest, Dame Judi might add that she is widely regarded in British theater circles as the greatest living English actress. But she knows that only a minuscule proportion of the world's population has seen her Cleopatra or Lady Macbeth, her brassy Mother Courage or her oddly young and sexually susceptible Lady Bracknell. She is well aware that there are at least two good reasons why she has achieved international renown only in her 60's.
docs.abstract: Benedict Nightingale profile of leading British stage actress Dame Judi Dench, who will star in play Amy's View, her first New York appearance in 40 years; photos (M)

headline.main: Who Is This Dame? Oh, Only a Queen of the Stage

docs.snippet: ONCE upon a golden age, a landmark American musical and a momentous American play opened on Broadway, less than two months apart, each making an instant leap from mainstream hit to mythic stature.    Because Broadway no longer represents accessibl...
docs.lead_paragraph: ONCE upon a golden age, a landmark American musical and a momentous American play opened on Broadway, less than two months apart, each making an instant leap from mainstream hit to mythic stature. Because Broadway no longer represents accessible essential magic, the golden anniversaries of the musical (''South Pacific'') and the drama (''Death of a Salesman'') define a golden age of everlasting enchanted evenings. For big-time commercial theater, the best of times was then.
docs.abstract: Croton Teen Theater will present production of Rodgers and Hammerstein musical South Pacific featuring Cass Morgan and Gerald Anthony and directed by Meg Bussert, Croton-on-Hudson, NY; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Nikita S. Mikhalkov, Russia's most celebrated living film director, has already won an Oscar for his 1995 movie, ''Burnt by the Sun.'' He has fame, fortune and, as many women fans would have it, is the epitome of Russian manhood.    But the talk n...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nikita S. Mikhalkov, Russia's most celebrated living film director, has already won an Oscar for his 1995 movie, ''Burnt by the Sun.'' He has fame, fortune and, as many women fans would have it, is the epitome of Russian manhood. But the talk now in Moscow -- a capital skittish with economic crisis, winter gloom and an obviously ailing head of state -- is that Mr. Mikhalkov might even run for President.
docs.abstract: Interview with Nikita S Mikhalkov, director of film The Barber of Siberia, who says he will weigh running for president himself if he cannot find candidate to support; possible candidacy reflects disillusionment Russians have with choices among infirm Pres Boris N Yeltsin and slew of pretenders widely seen as power-hungry opportunists; he calls for restoration of real or idealized virtues of Czarist Russia; photo (M)

headline.main: In Filmmaker's Ideal Russia, a Presidential Role?

docs.snippet: Barry McEvoy is a sometime actor and bartender from Northern Ireland who carries a perpetual verbal smirk and takes few things too seriously except his desire to make good in his chosen field. Movies, not pouring booze. So when he finished writing...
docs.lead_paragraph: Barry McEvoy is a sometime actor and bartender from Northern Ireland who carries a perpetual verbal smirk and takes few things too seriously except his desire to make good in his chosen field. Movies, not pouring booze. So when he finished writing his first script, a story about two barbers trying to make a go of it as hairpiece salesmen in Belfast, he did what seemed like the wise thing; he made a deal with the owner of the bar where he worked, in the East Village in Manhattan, to produce the film. Funnier things may have happened, but not much. And funnier yet, the film is being made with Mr. McEvoy, 31, in one of the lead parts and an enthusiastic group of producers behind the project.
docs.abstract: At the Movies column; Barry McEvoy, sometime actor and bartender from Northern Ireland, is filming An Everlasting Piece where he works, at St Dymphnas Restaurant and Bar in New York's East Village; film is about Catholic and Protestant barbers who try to sell hairpieces in Northern Ireland; New Line signs with writer-director Gregory Nava to make English-language films targeted to Latin audiences; David DiFrancesco discusses new animation technology he is developing for Pixar Animation Studios; photos (S)

docs.snippet: There was speculation during last week's World Boxing Council welterweight showdown between Oscar De La Hoya and Ike Quartey that Felix Trinidad, the International Boxing Federation welterweight champion, weighed as much as 156 pounds with less th...
docs.lead_paragraph: There was speculation during last week's World Boxing Council welterweight showdown between Oscar De La Hoya and Ike Quartey that Felix Trinidad, the International Boxing Federation welterweight champion, weighed as much as 156 pounds with less than two weeks to go before he climbed into the ring against Pernell Whitaker. Yesterday afternoon, before a news conference to publicize the fight, Trinidad's father, manager and trainer, Felix Sr., frowned at the assertion that his son is having trouble making the weight for Saturday's bout at Madison Square Garden.
docs.abstract: Welterweight champion Felix Trinidad's father, manager and trainer, Felix Sr, denies son is having trouble making weight for his bout against Pernell Whitaker, news conference (M)

headline.main: Trinidad: Tale of the Tape or Battle of the Bulge?

docs.snippet: A prominent American writer on gay themes who was beaten on Jan. 31 was in critical but stable condition here tonight, hospital officials said.    The writer, Robert Drake, 36, of Philadelphia, received ''severe head injuries'' in Sligo, the polic...
docs.lead_paragraph: A prominent American writer on gay themes who was beaten on Jan. 31 was in critical but stable condition here tonight, hospital officials said. The writer, Robert Drake, 36, of Philadelphia, received ''severe head injuries'' in Sligo, the police said. No one has been arrested.
docs.abstract: Robert Drake, prominent American writer on gay themes, is in critical but stable condition in Dublin following Jan 31 assault by two men in Sligo; two men reportedly told police they beat Drake after he made sexual overtures to them; no arrests have been made (M)

headline.main: U.S. Writer On Gay Topics Is Badly Beaten In an Irish City

docs.snippet: Since the end of the cold war, the Berlin Film Festival has given up its obsession with East-West issues in favor of frequent evocation of Germany's earlier -- Nazi -- past. No surprise, then, that this year's 49th festival should include two docu...
docs.lead_paragraph: Since the end of the cold war, the Berlin Film Festival has given up its obsession with East-West issues in favor of frequent evocation of Germany's earlier -- Nazi -- past. No surprise, then, that this year's 49th festival should include two documentaries and two feature films about the Nazi years. At a time of intense debate here over both compensation for Nazi victims and construction of a Holocaust Memorial in Berlin, the subject seems more topical than ever. Yet, for all that, ''Aimee and Jaguar,'' which opened the 11-day festival on Feb. 10, represents a significant change in the way German cinema addresses the Nazi era. By recounting a poignant true love story set in wartime Berlin between a Jewish woman and a non-Jewish mother of four, a German film has for the first time dared use the Nazi regime simply as the context for a human drama.
docs.abstract: German films shown at 49th annual Berlin Film Festival represent significant change in way German cinema addresses Nazi era; Max Farberbock's Aimee and Jaguar dares to use Nazi regime simply as context for human drama; Fernando Trueba's The Girl of My Dreams treats Nazi era with humor; photos (M)

headline.main: German Films At Festival Treat Nazis More Freely

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND OTHER MINORITIES

docs.snippet: No need to wait for Fleet Week to encounter the hardest-working crew in or out of New York Harbor. The men are on the job right now, at the Manhattan Theater Club, lifting anchor, dropping line, hoisting sails, swabbing decks, climbing masts, scal...
docs.lead_paragraph: No need to wait for Fleet Week to encounter the hardest-working crew in or out of New York Harbor. The men are on the job right now, at the Manhattan Theater Club, lifting anchor, dropping line, hoisting sails, swabbing decks, climbing masts, scaling fish and yes, even singing more prettily in multipart harmony than any a capella group from Princeton or Yale. They are the lusty, vocally trained sailors of ''Captains Courageous,'' the new musical based on the Rudyard Kipling novel about a blueblooded brat who falls off an ocean liner and into the lives of a Portuguese seaman and his mates on a New England fishing trawler. The show, which opened last night, features Treat Williams as the fearless Portuguese fisherman, Manuel; young Brandon Espinoza as the rich boy who earns his comeuppance and his sea legs, and 14 other able-bodied actors in an all-male cast who do so many ship-related chores they could turn in their Equity cards and immediately qualify for the seafarers' union.
docs.abstract: Peter Marks reviews Manhattan Theater Club production of Captains Courageous, new musical based on Rudyard Kipling novel; show features Treat Williams as Manuel; music is by Frederick Freyer and book and lyrics are by Patrick Cook; Lynne Meadow directs (M)

headline.main: Sailors Toil, And a Brat Earns His Sea Legs

docs.snippet: Remember the scene in ''Jurassic Park'' when the T. rex is chasing the car and the side mirror carries the warning about reflected objects being closer than they look? Some designers seem to be riding along oblivious to how close and how fast the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Remember the scene in ''Jurassic Park'' when the T. rex is chasing the car and the side mirror carries the warning about reflected objects being closer than they look? Some designers seem to be riding along oblivious to how close and how fast the new millennium is approaching. How else to explain why Marc Jacobs, one of the brightest and most lauded American fashion stars, should troll the 1970's and beyond for the fall 1999/winter 2000 collection he showed Monday night?
docs.abstract: Anne-Marie Schiro reviews fall designer fashion collections shown in New York, including clothes by Marc Jacobs, Hussein Chalayan and Max Azria; photos (M)

headline.main: Review/Fashion; Warmth and Wearability, But Where's the Surprise?

docs.snippet: De LISO-Agrippina of Sagaponack, New York. Died February 14 at age 83. Devoted wife of the late writer, Oscar De Liso; dear mother of Monica and mother-in-law of Herbert Hellman; beloved grandmother of Andrew; cherished sister of Dr. Helen Scire a...
docs.lead_paragraph: De LISO-Agrippina of Sagaponack, New York. Died February 14 at age 83. Devoted wife of the late writer, Oscar De Liso; dear mother of Monica and mother-in-law of Herbert Hellman; beloved grandmother of Andrew; cherished sister of Dr. Helen Scire and Yolanda La Vecchia; adored aunt of many nieces and nephews. Mrs. De Liso graduated from Hunter College in 1937 and attained her Masters degree in Social Work from Columbia University in 1956. She worked at Rockland County's first mental health clinic for eight years, was a supervisor at Pleasantville Cottage School for eight years and a faculty advisor for New York University School of Social Work before retiring in 1972. Her great passions were dancing, traveling and the scholarly pursuit of everything. She was a woman of style and will be greatly missed.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LISO, AGRIPPINA
